38794810.review:
Great game, but definetely requires a certain mindset.

TL;DR and verdict at bottom, skip if you need to.

The plot is pretty basic, transfer student, new school, new friends. The mecha stuff is all pretty basic anime stuff too, and they don't actually play THAT big of a role. That being said, ACE Academy does do some things differently that other visual novels most certainly do not.

Let's start with

[h1] The Positives [/h1]

- [b]Western writing[/b]
This might seem like a strange remark, but the writing is very obviously NOT done by "professionals". It feels a lot like a fan-sub or something, and some of the jokes are very off-putting at first, untill you get used to them at least. 

One of my favourite parts about this, and why I consider it a positive, is that no jokes are lost in translation or anything like that. There are tons of refferences that any decently well-established anime and video games fan can understand, everything from Gladiator (movie), Power Rangers and Metal Gear Solid has a small refference, and while it does take out some of the seriousness, I don't think it goes so far as to disrupt the actual experience.

- [b]Still anime[/b]
This might seem like a negative, but as I mentioned, it's really more a case of getting used to it. The writing can seem really chessy, cliché and silly at the start but, at least in my case, you get used to it, and it actually becomes really charming and endearing.

Especially towards the end, the games actually becomes really wholesome, and a character that used to be comic relief, actually has some really touching moments, while still staying in character. When I thought back about it, it really reminds me of some of my favourite animes, and just like anime in general, you have to get used to the way the story is presented.

- [b]Voice acting[/b]
Original English Voice Acting. Few anime-related games with actual good English voice acting actually exist, most of them either go way overboard or fall completely flat, mainly due to most dubs being made by either pros who don't really know what they are dealing with, or complete amateurs who despite trying their best, end up going a bit too far.

A few good examples, like the Full Metal Alchemist dub and Sunrider come to mind, and this game definetely makes it to the list as well. The voice actors manage to capture the kind of over-emotional nature of anime without going completely overboard. A lot of the voice acting was very impressive to listen to, and the actors really nail the anime tone, which I can definetely appreciate.

- [b]Actually engaging writing[/b]
With all the unusuals out of the way, ACE Academy is also just a really well written visual novel! It's a bit cheery, sometimes I kind of missed some REAL tragedy, but it's good at what it does. One of the things I personally really enjoyed was the fact that your potential love interests actually find their own girl/boyfriends without you, and you get to watch it happen. This was, for me, one of the first times I had witnessed something like this, and I loved it! It's incredibly heart-warming, not to mention refreshing since for once the entire universe doesn't revolve around you.

Despite not actually getting a girl in my first run (I stuck with the bro-dude), it was still such a warm and nice experience.


[h1] The Negatives [/h1]

The two first positives could be viewed as negatives. It's a matter of taste, but I'm guessing most people even showing interest in the game will already be aware of the anime nature of it's being, so let's get to the actual negatives.

- [b] It's too good [/b]
Everything goes a little too well in my opinion, and making to go well is incredibly easy. Especially considering how open the ending is, with it cutting off right before any interesting drama could occur, the game felt a tad too sweet. I appreciate that there was no edgy under-plot (I think Doki-Doki drained me of my desire for that, even that game was a bit too far for me tbh), but I would have still liked some sort of hurdle to overcome.

Still, the game does have its fair share of mysteries and drama, just nothing that wasn't resolved very quickly. The exception being the thing with your dad, which, again, you never really get to see the actual conclusion of.

- [b] The Battles [/b]
The actual mech battles are incredibly dissapointing. Coming from a game like Sunrider or even Kamidori or some Rance game into this will leave you starving for a more interesting distraction from dialogue. Personally, I didn't mind it too much, since it fits the already light-hearted and casual nature of the VN itself, but I do feel like it's a missed oppurtunity. I sure as hell would have loved some Sunrider-esque turn-based mech action, instead of the incredibely easy timed choices.

The game focuses more on dialogue than this, and the art is still decent, so this might be more of a let-down for some more than others.


[h1] TL;DR [/h1]

ACE Academy is a very wholesome and heart-warming experience, that still manages to not be too aimless and casual, having it's fair share of memorable, funny and/or thoughtful moments. The art is average in skill, but impressive in passion, the music is bland and unmemorable, but enhances the experience well, and the writing is fantastic.

While it lacks any real tension, at least any that lasts for very long, it still manages to grip the reader consistently with great character building, passion and heartwarming moments! A real feel good game.

All in all, I would recommend ACE Academy to anyone who likes choose-your-own-adventure style visual novels. Plenty of routes to explore in this one, which adds enough hours to warrant the price tag, at least in my opinion.

If you liked the plot and feel of games like Sunrider, then you should pick this up immediately!

[h1] Verdict [/h1]

A solid

[b] 7 / 10 [/b]

A feel-good game that is excellently written, and oozing with funny and memorable moments that had me reacting in a way that few stories do. Good length and replayability too, great job!

38531338.review:
I know some of you might be hesitant in paying the full price for a visual novel. Believe me, I was, too. In fact, the only reason I got into this game was because it was on sale. And after playing the full game.. I can honestly say it would have been worth the full price. The art style, voice acting, characters, and everything about it is phenomenal. This game has become my favorite visual novel and one of my favorite games I've played in 2017. There's a wide assortment of unique characters, and the romance was very well executed. Even if you already settle on a romantic interest, every other character still plays a big role in the story, which is something I respect. It gives off a Persona vibe, too, which the game actually even references! There are a lot of references in the game, some of them are of dead memes which might make you cringe, but I was laughing quite a bit through the game. 

The game is also immersive. Meaning your choices ACTUALLY matter. You're not just watching and reading dialogue the entire time. You get to choose the direction the story goes in and there were quite a few decisions that left me stumped.

My only complaint was the ending, which was in and itself, a good thing. The ending's really abrupt, but it makes you wanting so much more. It's a game you have to play for yourself. Don't be turned away from the idea of visual novels in general or the cost, because it's an experience well worth it.

I cannot stress how much this game has hit me in the feels.

It definitely has replay value but... I feel hungry for a sequel.

38292212.review:
I don't write many reviews but this VN was satisfying to a point where I feel like I should. First and foremost, I will say that this is s visual novel, so if that isn't you thing, or you aren't really into anime and manga, you probably won't fully appreciate the game. 

Ha, now that those losers are outta here, I can describe why I enjoyed ACE Academy. It starts with a clever personality choice that grants access to a few different dialogues and changes elements about your character. You can name your character however you choose as well. The story sets up in an interesting way and it doesn't take more than an hour or so before you know all the main characters. The day to day ingame may seem like a dating sim more than a VN but after a little while, the story really picks up and gives an engaging plot for you to follow, while simulataneously persuing one of four female characters as a romance (or you can stay single and just be a really good friend, although there's bound to be one character you like). Each character feels like an expansion of tropes we've seen in other works but they all feel realistic enough. You've got the quiet, introvert character (who admittedly, I didn't spend much time with, purely personal preferece), you have the angry, competitive type who has a soft side with kids, there's the sensitive, intelligent girl (she was my preference), and finally you have the flirty, blond who happens to be a genius engineer. They all play their roles wonderfully, and don't feel ripped from other VNs and anime.

As it's a slice of life, you'd expect it to be funny. It is. For the most part. The MC gets the opportunity to say most of the funniest things if you so please, but for most of the characters, your jokes seem to fall flat. I wish there was a better response to humor with the characters but thats just me, probably. 

There's an astounding number of references to everything included in dialogue too. For example, television shows in-universe include: Breaking GEARs, How I Met Your GEAR, That 70s GEAR, etc (all of which have some funny accompanying dialogue in reference to there real counterparts. Movies in-universe include: The Lord of the GEARS and the like. There's a sequence where one character dresses up as Yu Narukami from Persona 4, only to be ridiculed and compared to Yosuke Hanamura (I love Persona and freaked), and a little bit after, the characters play "The King's Game" from the same property (if you don't know what I am talking about, either play the game, its fantastic, or watch the anime, also fantastic. The specific episode to watch for the kings game is ep. 15). Even further, a character is a blatant reference to Alex Louis Armstrong from FullMetal Alchemist and it's remake, Brotherhood. There is plenty more and I'll let some be a surprise but know that the referencial humor is hilarious (to me, at least.)

I was happy to spend the five dollars I had on this VN, as I was given an enjoyable narrative, accompanied by a compelling romance and will probably replay the game soon to see how else it could play out. It's a little long for a VN that you are supposed to be able to replay, but that's not really a problem, just an observation from my end.

If you're reading this, PixelFade, I'm waiting on ACE Academy: Supernova.

36641144.review:
Thoughts after first playthrough:

Story
The story centers around a young man training to become a mech pilot. It's a fun premise that doesn't really go anywhere - It doesn't really build up to anything. There's no climax against a villain, or achieving a goal. The story ends abruptly without much payoff. This story is more about the journey than the destination. It's about individual moments, and the people in your character's life, which it does do well.

Characters
The MC is shaped by the dialogue and action choices you make through the game, so he can be anywhere from charming to pervy, cowardly to courageous based on how you want to play him. While many of the NPCs are tropes, they are familiar and well characterized. There are some genuinely funny and touching moments. I wanted to see them succeed and be happy.

Gameplay
You'd expect a game about giant robot battles to have more giant robot battles in it. I think in the whole game there is maybe three battles, which boil down to quicktime events. It would have been nice to have some impact on strategy or mech upgrades etc. The game has the dating-sim tag, but it's not really about buying them gifts, silly mini-games or anything tedious like that. Basically, when you have free time you hang out with your Waifu of choice and pick the dialogue choice you think they'd most like to hear. 

Conclusion
ACE academy has some good ideas in it, and the characters are interesting. I like the artwork, the full english voice acting and the music is enjoyable. The problem is that there isn't a whole lot for the player to do. It's much more a novel than it is a game. I would be fine with that if the story was a little more intereting with a stronger climax and ending. I fully recommend it on sale ~$5-10, I would not pay $21.99 for it as it is currently listed.

Everything about this visual novel is great; The story, the choices you can make, the art, the voice acting, and other aspects make this, I dare say, the best visual novel I've ever played.

36478539.review:
ACE Academy (PC - Steam) - 6,5/10
Легкая (в плане настроения) и забавная визуальная новелла, относительно качественная, но не особо глубокая в сюжетном плане. Подойдет чтобы убить время и немного посмеяться, но не ждите от нее слишком многого.

Приятная, но простоватая рисовка. Задников не хватает - для многих локаций используются одни и те же фоны, которые порой совершенно не подходят. Третьестепенные персонажи вообще не нарисованы - просто черные силуэты. Если бы это встречалось пару раз за игру - я бы не обратил внимания, но поскольку таких локаций и персонажей очень много - игра ощущается просто-напросто недоделанной. Это можно частично оправдать большим количеством локаций и персонажей, но все же наличие уникальных (или хотя бы чуть измененных) фонов/моделек сильно улучшило бы общие впечатления. Озвучены почти все диалоги (кроме протагониста), но некоторые реплики пропущены частично или полностью (кстати, о недоделках). Озвучка, судя по всему, не профессиональная, есть неровности, но в целом приятная, некоторые особо удачные моменты хочется прослушивать по нескольку раз (тут помогает функция перемотки). Музыка ничем не выделяется. Сюжета особого нет - играем за студента пилотирующего мехов, осваиваемся в футуристичной Японии, учимся, заводим друзей, влюбляемся, участвуем в соревнованиях и все в таком духе. Основная сюжетная линия прорисовывается лишь к середине, но так толком и не раскрывается. В диалогах много развилок и реплик, которые никак не влияют на развитие истории, но добавляют возможность по-разному обыграть различные ситуации, увидеть уникальные сцены и взглянуть на персонажей с разных сторон. В наличии легкий юмор, много отсылок к современным фильмам, играм и т.п., почти нет фансервиса и пошлостей. Персонажи по-началу кажутся слишком шаблонными, но все же со временем немного раскрываются. К тому же мы сами решаем с кем и когда общаться - даже начав романтические отношения с одной из героинь, мы все равно можем видеться с остальными. Правда с этим связаны и некоторые недоработки - мы так и не узнаем ответы на некоторые вопросы и не увидим как завершатся события, которые игрок пропустит, плюс, в разговоре можно встретить отсылки к событиям, которых на самом деле не было (т.к. ты проводил это время с другими персонажами), но случаются такие несостыковки достаточно редко. Добавляет героиням жизни и тот факт, что они не помешаны на главном герое, как это бывает в дешевых фансервисных новеллах - со всеми из них можно быть просто друзьями, да и часть из них будут строить свои отношения с кем-то еще, если у вас с ними ничего не сложится. Не ко всем героям я так уж сильно проникся, но вместе они хорошо дополняют друг-друга и создают множество курьезных ситуаций. События Ace Academy разворачиваются крайне неспешно, на прохождение игры у меня ушло почти двадцать часов, но концовка при этом чувствуется недоделанной и обрывается ничем. Проект целиком и полностью завязан на отношениях с персонажами и юморе, а основная сюжетная линия, соревнования на мехах и повседневная рутина служат лишь фоном и поводом для развития этих отношений и возникновения комичных ситуаций.

36331306.review:
This is a visual novel that wasn't developed for perverts. Well, kinda... Anyway, maybe all the reviews of VN's that are a point outside of the curve should begin like that, but that's what happens after having to carry a stigma related to the genre for so many years.

Well then, the story is about this guy and his sister who have recently moved to Japan to live with their uncle after their parents' death. The guy you control is good with mechas and stuff, and the girl fulfills her role perfectly (like a real sister). Through this premise, you get to meet some people throughout the way (mostly girls, of course), and... Yeah, you know it. You get to choose who's the most interesting character and then you go chase after them.

Now let's take a look on the game's aspects: The story is pretty basic (in my opinion). The soundtrack and effects are kinda decent, can't complain about them. The art is really neat, but I didn't really like the voice acting. As for the length, you can get to kill quite a good amount of time and try some different choices until you've done everything that's available. Even though this game has cloud saving, I'm still trying to understand why in the world it doesn't have achievements nor trading cards. Please try to implement these in the future, devs.

Overall, if you're a fan of the visual novel genre and is the kind of person who'd rather play the games because of the story rather than the naughty stuff (which usually comes included in the package), then this is a good alternative for you.

36315385.review:
This game somehow manages to take mecha battles and make them incredibly boring. I guess that's what they call "slice of life" in other reviews; I found it dull. Some of the characters are vaguely interesting, but they play on the usual harem tropes without making them their own. We have a shy girl, a tomboy girl, an overly flirty girl, and a girl whose characterization is fully expressed in words "nice with big boobs". Oh and the little sister who is adorable and likes to cook. What an exciting line-up.

Steam says I played this game for over 10 hours, but it felt like twice that. I kept waiting for the plot to actually pick up, but it just... didn't. It felt like it was just there as a vehicle for girl delivery. And okay, that's the case with most romantic-focused visual novels, but in this game it just felt. so. long. and. so. laborious. The writing itself is gramatically sound but bland across the board. Things that were supposed to be funny were not actually funny, and things that were supposed to be endearing were not endearing.

Overall I could have spent those hours reading fanfiction for more entertaining results.

Bought this game while it was on sale a while back and didn't regret it at all. I fully enjoyed this game, the concept of the game (people going to school to learn to pilot mechs) has been used loads of times already but despite this, the plot is really different from others I have seen in Anime and other Visual Novels. Going back to my point about the plot, not only was it different but also very interesting, a certain level of business intrigue and mystery with some really well laid out emotional moments. Overall my only complaint is that there is no follow up out yet! If PixelFade ever made or plan to make a follow up to this game I would definitely support it!

36090673.review:
TL;DR: A solid entry and heartily recommended.

This is basically the first VN of this type I've played (after the nightmare that is Doki Doki Literature Club made me aware of the genre), so if you're new like me you may relate to my perspective: I never thought much about VNs as they weren't "real" games in my eyes and -tbh- I still feel the same way. However, I always liked those Chose-Your-Own-Adventure books as a child, as they gave you some agency instead of just passively consuming. 
Well, this is that but with way more focus on the characters, which I found to be actually quite believable, despite each of them obviously adhering to a common stereotype, though they each have their own bagckstory to discover, gaining some depth as the game progresses. 
The story is basically a concatenation of mostly unrelated scenarios with the other characters in either your free time or during the mecha-fights, which lend the game its futuristic theme. There is somewhat of an underlying conspiracy plot going on, which however is resolved a little unspectacularly. It still kept my intereset the whole way, though. 
The game has a lot of choices to make and most have three options to choose from. I do not think most make a big difference, but each one makes a scenario play out in a different way, making it your own expirence despite arriving at the same end situation. Mostly, your choice is to either relate to the character you're speaking to, make a reasonable argument or some quip/perverted remark. Although I found, that even the "BOOBIES!"-kind of dialouge choices were something I could see at least other actually saying. It was also a bit longer than expected at 14h played which was a nice surprise, although I might add I'd consider myslef a slow reader.
If I have one gripe with this game it is, that what is has in substance it lacks in resources and polish. Frequently reused backrounds often don't reflect what the story is telling (e.g. a crowded room is empty in the background) and charcters basically appear in a single standing pose except for some special occasions during the game. The faces of the girls seem to alll have the same shape with a pointed chin and the biggest difference seems to be in stature and attire. I'm glad to say though, that the faces nicely change expression in every situation you're in, so the focus of the budget was on the spot from my perspective. I would say that the voice acting felt very off at times, but english is my second language so take that with a grain of salt. I just turned it off in the settings and I was happier for it.

If you'd excuse me now, I need to revisit some choices I've made and see if I can romance the girl that always seems to hate on me for some reason. :-)

35745042.review:
ACE Academy is a story-rich visual novel developed and published by PixelFade Inc.. Following your little sister as she begins her studies in a new country, you find yourself transferring to ACE Academy which is a premier school for Cenorobotic studies in Japan. "Cenorobotics" is a new academic field dealing with the study and use of GEARs which are giant mechanized robots originally developed for military applications. The popularity of arena GEAR combat has enveloped a number of different areas with engineering, sponsorship, entertainment and weapons development just to name a few. How will you and your sister adjust to life in a different nation, will you be able to make friends or possibly find love and most importantly will your piloting skills position you and your GEAR at the top of the Cenorobotics program? Welcome to Japan.

Usually I skip the gameplay portion of a visual novel review because it's a visual novel and there is no gameplay...until now that is...sort of? Strangely enough, there actually is some gameplay involved in ACE Academy whenever there is combat with the mechs or GEARs as they are properly refered to. On the battlefield, as advances are made by you and your opponents you are quickly given a list of actions to make with your GEAR and you only have a very limited time, seconds at best as a countdown timer initiates, to make a choice which really adds to the tension of the battles. Do you block, evade, fire weapons or go in for a melee attack...it's all very well executed into the story quite nicely with animations during the battles. In summary, this additional dynamic really had me even more intrigued with the narrative in ACE Academy as I found myself eagerly looking forward to the next engagements with the GEARs.

Visually, this novel is really stunning with it's top notch illustration and professional presentation. The manga inspired artwork is some of the best I've seen in any V.N. and is filled with bright cheerful colors and terrific shading. Even the menu screens are beautifully done which shows the commitment that this development team really put into this title. One very eye-catching feature is the animation of the characters in this story. They certainly aren't the static 2D figures that you see in most visual novels no. The people in ACE Academy are wonderfully animated. Their mouths move when they speak, their eyes blink, they even show different emotions with their facial features like blushing and getting upset or angry. Sometimes even cute little speech bubbles with different animations in them like a heart or a tear pop up over the characters heads depending on what they just said or what they're feeling it's all very manga-like and fun to observe as you read the engrossing narrative. They also change clothing on a regular basis, whenever you meet someone outside of the Academy for a social engagement they are always wearing something different. I found this to be a wonderful little detail and something that you don't often see in most visual novels. On another note, the sound is of the upmost quality. It's truly immersive as the development team has managed to include ambient noises such as doors opening/closing, phones ringing, birds chirping, vehicles etc., basically all the sounds you would hear as the characters interact with each other and their environments as the story progresses. I really love it when these sounds are incorporated into the V.N. because it truly immmerses me within the story. ACE Academy has voiced dialogue and typically I like my V.N.'s without it but I must admit that the voice actors in this title have done an impressive job with the script. I find them all endearing and quite believable in what they say and how they say it. Also, your little sister Nikki has the cutest voice ever. In conclusion, with all the effort put forth in just the visuals and sound quality of ACE Academy you would be hard pressed to find another visual novel with as outstanding a presentation as this.

To date, ACE Academy has been without a doubt the best and one of the longest visual novel experiences that I've had on Steam. The story is extremely well written and quite entertaining and some of the more emotional scenes will even bring a tear or two to your eyes. There are many unique characters to interact with and an abundance of choices to make throughout the branching narrative and let's not forget the fun GEAR combat. There is also a ton of "pop culture" references thrown at you in this V.N. so that was an added bonus as well. As far as options go, there are the basics for audio, video and text speed. Also included is an unlockable CG gallery and a very memorable original soundtrack with a few homage bonus tracks thrown in for good measure. Sadly there are no Steam Achievements or Steam Trading Cards to collect which is a shame because those would go over nicely with this title. As most of the V.N.'s that I've tried on Steam have been fantasy based or occuring in present day, it was very refreshing to finally get a quality title that was purely science fiction. In conclusion, featuring a truly intriguing story in which you actually get to pilot a mech, amazing artwork, a rich cast of memorable characters and a terrific O.S.T., ACE Academy is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to visual novel fans, anyone wanting to experience a great sci-fi story and definitely to anyone wanting to try a visual novel for the very first time.

35534407.review:
Short review - Worth the price for sure. Good art. Solid sountrack. And I enjoyed the premise of the story. The dialogue was well-written and I laughed more than a few times. However there is one pretty large caveat and there will be spoilers in the the full review. However, I would reccomend the game, especially if you pick it up on sale. It's a yes from me.

***********************************

Full review

The game is made in the Ren'py engine. From personal experience, VNs made in Ren'py tend to crash from time to time and have a few minor bugs. I found none of that in ACE Academy (known as AA from here on out) so that counts as major points in PixelFade's favor. Kudos on simply a *well-made* game. Can tell a lot of effort went into crafting this game. 

The game also has English V/Os. Voice Acting in VNs is always appreciated as long as it doesn't detract/distract from the writting. And that's not the case here. At worst, it's servicable. The only way it could detract would be if it was bad and that's not the case here at all. I would say there's a standout, but the primary characters all good a good job. Some of the dialogue is cheesy, but I'm not going to hold that against the V/As. They made it work.

The dialogue is well-written for the most part. Standard cliches aside, there's a very intriguiging story here and I found myself getting invested in the characters. I wanted them to suceed. I was rooting for them, Some of the dialogue is genuninely amusing and I found myself laughing more than a few times. AA is also HORRENDOUSLY cheesy at times and I find real-world references tend to "date" games. It's fine to fill your game up with time period references if you're making a game that's supposed to have a retro-atmosphere or there's a particular theme you're chasing (such as a movie intentionally paying homage to 80s action flicks or B-movie shlock). GEARs of Thrones? How I Met Your GEARs? That doesn't even make sense.

The only negative is that for as much as I enjoyed the writting and the story in general, the ending for AA is absolutely a bust. The game unmistakably feels incomplete. There's is NO getting around it. The game just ends JUST as it seems the story is starting to get REALLY interesting. I understand PixalFade is not CDProjektRed or Bethesda or another AAA developer and you can only do so much on a given budget. It almost feels unfair because PixelFade seems like an Indie developer you should all support. It's clear that there's more story capable of being fleshed out and for that reason I hope to encourage people to buy this game and support this company. Maybe the project might have been a little too ambitious but they should be praised for their vision and AA is nearly a great realization of it.

Instead it's merely good. But IS good. And occasionally great. But I won't hold their vision against them.

Support PixelFade, guys

My one major complain though is that rushed ending, from what I understand there was a lack of funding and that's why it is the way it is. 35509154.review:
Pros:
- The other girls' lives doesn't revolve around you. Unlike other VNs I read, their lives and interaction doesn't stop completely once you have picked out a route. I was surprised that other characters had found a relationship even without the MCs urging, especially since these other characters can be romanced as well. You could also hang out with them even after locking into another route which is a huge plus because in other VNs they fade into obscurity with the spotlight shining towards your route. (ehem Katawa Shoujo)
- Comedy and Fourth-wall breaks.

Cons
- MC's story was unsatisfying.
- The final match was unsatisfying.
- Some dialogues are different from what is said, to what is written in box below.
- No explanation on what key is skip, auto mode, etc.
- Backgrounds are recycled in some parts. When tutoring in the daycare you get the BG from the library at ACE, any lobby from other places gets you the Pilot's lounge, among others.


Routes:
Yuuna & Valerie>Kaori>Mayu
Yuuna and Valerie are my two favorite routes. Yuuna was just a sweet-heart and the comedy sprinkled during her route was just fantastic. Valerie, on the other hand was the best complement to the MC if you choose his flirtatious responses all the time. 

Kaori and Mayu was meh. Kaori was just a tsundere and that was what she has going for her. Mayu would have been better had her father been introduced to the MC and an arc about how her father disapproves or something would be better, and the surprise Yandere Mayu was just too OOC IMO. 


Recommendation: If you like a VN that isn't heavily-focused on drama or a thought-provoking story and instead focuses on comedy, buy this game.

Price: Buy it during sales. The story was really unsatisfying to justify buying the game full-priced.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS. But who cares, as if this game actually haves plots.

This game is a huge disappointment. The artwork looks nice, the overwhelmingly positive reviews seem promising, but you never know until you yourself got to play it.

The background of this game doesn't make any sense. Students are trained to pilot the Gears, but what are the Gears for? Where would the pilots go when they graduate? I don't get any insight from this game.

The main plot doesn't make any sense. You would think there is conspiracy behind MC's parents' death, but none. It turns out the police is right! It is an accident. And MC's father died for nothing. He destroyed his research, which may introduce new weapon that is 15x more powerful than nuclear weapon, because he fears it may be abused. But even nuclear weapon itself varies in power, the most powerful is over 10000x powerful than the weakest, yet we don't have a nuclear war.

Girls' plots don't make any sense. Some personal scenes, interactions, that is all. No depth, no ending, no nothing,

This game is unfinished. Please people, take responsibility, stop hyping it.

34223403.review:
Mostly spoiler-less review of ACE Academy, includes some but they are marked with spoiler tags, so don't worry!


Even though I didn't play TOO much of this VN (heck, I can say you can't have enough of this), I still find it a very well made one, easily one of the best so far. I had no issues with the game overall, being made by a Western team and having English dub as a base only makes it more enjoyable. The story is also alright, but there is much more to this game which I'll be covering.


Like others mentioned, it's easily noticed that the cast has some very well-known anime trope characters, but that's not an issue (for me at least), and each cast member (even the side ones who also have voices!) was unique in their own way. Not wanting to spoiler the story and what you'll see for you, I'll just go ahead with the "good and bad".

GOOD POINTS : 

+The overall design : Choices. That. Actually. Matter! A nameable protagonist! Fight scenes! Multiple romance routes! English dub with just about everyone voiced! These points pretty much explain it. [spoiler]some may say the fight scenes were mediocre but actually I really enjoyed them.[/spoiler]. Speaking of choices. there really are a lot of them, and choices made may, sometimes, affect the choices afterward! I won't be getting into these examples to avoid some major spoilers, but you'll see for yourself.

+Price : With it's length, multiple romance routes and HUNDREDS of choices, comprared to other VN's, 20 euros is an extremely generous price. It sometimes even goes on sale (I got it for 5 euros), in which case it's basically a steal!

34202629.review:
I've only just started playing visual novels and dating sims, but so far, ACE Academy is my favorite of those genres. There's a lot to like.

You make choice after choice after glorious choice as you guide your main character through his new life in Japan as a transfer student in piloting at ACE Academy (which reviewers call a high school but seems to me to definitely be a university). You join a team and pilot your GEAR (robot/mecha) through various battle matches, which are quick and simple to play and are bookended by strategy sessions and postmatch analysis. You go to classes and sit through or skip lessons and assignments. You adjust to a new family life at home with your charming little sister Nikki and your fun uncle Kaito. You have natural, rich, meaningful relationships with your friends and teammates. You crack jokes, play pranks, and encounter numerous weird pop culture references. And through all this, you learn about your GEAR and what connection it may have to the loss of your parents. All of this makes ACE Academy a fun yet moving game that took me about ten hours on the first playthrough. (Steam says I have 3 hours, but it stopped counting after the first day for some reason.)

What this game handles best of all is the relationships between the characters. With so many choices, you have a lot of control over the main character (although not complete control: occasionally he does something I wouldn't do or chose not to do). The game is long enough for the characters to reveal their depth, to one another as well as to you. And the relationships develop naturally. 

On my first time through, I decided not to pursue any of the four possible girls but instead stay open to whatever might happen. I spent time with the girl I liked the most, but then she signaled that she was uneasy about our feelings and didn't want to pursue them, so I backed off and we became great friends. Meanwhile, I was unsure about another girl, and I took things as slowly as I could... which gave us the chance to really get to know each other, until one day she said something that made me realize that what was happening between us was real, so I chose to kiss her, and we ended up in such a close relationship that by story's end, I felt sure that our characters would end up marrying each other after graduation.

Some reviewers are disappointed with the story's ending, feeling that it's a big buildup with no payoff, but I found it satisfying. In my playthrough, the major plot points were resolved in a striking way [spoiler] (instead of a conspiracy to kill my parents and steal my GEAR's technology, it turns out to be the other way around, that my father put technology in my GEAR that he shouldn't have, and his death was an accident) [/spoiler], yet leaving the satisfying feeling that these characters still have their lives ahead of them. Even though our story ends, theirs will go on.

There are a few quibbles with this game. For example, some of the backgrounds get reused, the pop culture references can be a bit over the top sometimes, and I wish there were an option to make the main character's relationship with his sister sweeter and more supportive without the teasing. And the story is so deep that it might keep me from replaying the game any time soon. The game seems to let you skip scenes that you've played before, but I would want the whole experience again... and if I take another route it might be bittersweet to meet my girlfriend again knowing that we're not getting together this time.

All in all, ACE Academy is an immersive, intriguing, fun game with mostly likeable characters, and a story that you get to participate in with active choices rather than just passively observe. You'll have to decide for yourself if you like it, but I really do. Highly recommended.




(I never guessed I would fall so deeply in love with [spoiler] Valerie Belle. [/spoiler])

It was a great visual novel and much more that the sum of its parts but I'll go into those parts anyways below. The short answer about this game is that if you like VN's, several choices of women in dating sims, a cute and funny slice of life story placed in the future you will like this game. For those who have come to this game to experience the "story" rather than the dating sim turn away now. Many parts of the story including the "ending" are driven by your choices in the datiing sim.
All in all I will reccomend this game, my full review is below.

The dating sim worked well, and unlike many other VN's of this type there was no question as to who you want to date. The game figuired that out based on a couple of your early game decisions. The way that they did it made everything feel very natrual. The dating sim portion gets a 10/10

The fighting sequences were easy, and the engine that they were using to program it doesn't usually support combat sequences so the way that they went about it was fairly smart, however there are other games that used the same engine that did it better such as the SUNRIDER series. Unlike the sunrider series though, if you fail by scrolling up you can try again. The Fighting sequence get a 5/10 for lack of action.

The story was amazing. It took me about 5 hours to complete one path and then only a couple of hours to complete the others. i skipped quite a bit on those other playthrough because I wanted to look at the ending. The plot was amazing however the ending left a little to be desired. There was no denouement or in layman's terms resolution to the story. The main conflict that drove a huge portion of the story is never resolved. For that I have to give the story a inc/10 for being incomplete.

I give this game a 8.5/10 with 1 point being able to be earned back by either making a sequel or by adding onto the story, and .5 being redeemable if they ever fix their combat sequences.

33980971.review:
ACE Academy is one of the best western visual novels I've played to date, even if quite limited in scope. It doens't offer incredible production qualities, as it was made by an indie team and the story is not as expansive as in some top-tier games in this genre. The replay value is also a bit limited, as your choices in most cases don't radically change the storyline or provide very distinct endings like in School Days or Fruit of Grisaia.

Still, while not as "big" as those Japanese games I mentioned above, it presents an engaging, well-written story with tasteful approach to both the main intrigue and the romance arcs. All characters are distinct enough and have intriguing qualities that makes you want to learn their stories and see different interactions protagonist might have with them. They do not deviate much from the typical tropes of the genre (a shy girl, a tsundere etc.), but they're done well enough to be entartaining and not completely predictable. The two romance arcs I've followed (Yunna and Kaori) were both really well done and compelling and the family storyline of the protagonist, especially his interactions with younger sister, were surprisingly good. The art and music complements the story properly and while the game would probably benefit from more sprites and more dedicated drawings for various scenes, it never felt "cheap" enough to make it problematic.

Also, as I suggested earlier, I very much liked the approach to romance it took, even though some my find it overly tame. I find this aspect of many visual novels rather exploitative than compelling and the slow pace of the relationships here felt very much natural and appropriate for the characters. Also, the "dating sim" component never dominated the story and rather complemented it, with benefits for both aspects of the game.

One negative I will have to mention is that with the limited replayability and around 7-8 hours for full playthrough, for many it probably won't be worth the full asking price of 20$. I've bought it on -75% sale and was very satisfied with the content provided, but I think paying more than 10$ would be a bit too much.

33954548.review:
I picked up the game for about $5 and I played through this game twice already... and really enjoyed it! For folks who are on the fence, let me give you a quick breakdown:

1) ACE ACADEMY is a visual novel. It's basically a semi-interactive book. Don't worry about needing to mash keys, monitor stats, or remember facts. You're mostly reading, and making dialogue choices. 

2) The game is mostly a dating sim, not a combat sim. - You'll play as a male protagonist who encounters four female love interests. Part of the fun of the game is exploring the relationships and taking them to their conclusion. 

3) It's done in an anime style! - If you enjoy animes, don't think twice, just pick up the game. You'll instantly recognize the tropes, character types, stereotypes, etc. Even if you don't watch a lot of anime, you'll recognize some very familiar territory in this game.



Playing this game *(and enjoying it) comes down to which love interest you'd like to pursue:



Yuuna - standard 'good' girl anime girl. Sweet, caring, a little motherly, encouraging, and fun.

Kaori - athletic, spicy, hot-tempered, competitive, and VERY conservative.

Mayu - brainy, shy, a little nerdy, serious, soft-spoken, gentle, and creative.

Valerie - bombastic, larger-than-life, flirtatous, and a bit of a bad girl 


The novel is super easy to enjoy, the characters all feel unique to each other, and part of the fun is playing it again and making different choices to see how it plays out. The stakes are super low, there's no way to 'lose' the game and have to start over, and you can rewind your decisions at any time or reload a save. 

Have fun guys!!! I did!

33901467.review:
+ Main cast are standard anime tropes, but likeable
+ Several girls to get your dating sim on, and thus replay value
+ You are not the center of the universe (see below)
+ Number of enjoyable, selectable scenes to get to know the characters
+ Quality of CGs and sprites, it's a "cute" game
+ Interesting setting and good world-building

o Combat is infrequent and bland enough to be unnecessary
o Reused backgrounds and silhouettes for many side characters
o Forgettable but passable soundtrack

- Many story elements feel rushed and half-baked (see below)
- Voice acting, particularly for secondary characters, is weak
- Far too many pop culture references that will age the game terribly

ACE Academy is tough for me to review. There's plenty to like about it, but it's clear that it's PixelFade's first effort, and suffers from its original episodic release. I assume the latter was a budgetary requirement to raise more funds through Early Access, but it's probably responsible for some pacing and focus issues.

First, I will elaborate on the "pro" above: you are not the center of the universe. You can pursue a variety of romance options, and beyond that choose which friends you spend free time with. I was pleasantly surprised to find that characters I didn't pursue still clearly had a life outside of the game's scenes. Girl who hit on me constantly that I rebuffed? She got another boyfriend. Standoffish teammate that I avoided until the end? All the while she was working at a daycare and has a heart of gold.

Now, the "con," which ties into my point about PixelFade and the episodic release. Story elements, like a big, brewing conspiracy and the fate of your family, are repeatedly teased and then tied up far too quickly and cleanly. There's some build up, but no climax, no payoff. So why include them at all, really? I suspect as they released episodes the game expanded in ways PixelFade didn't plan, and came to a point where their limited resources required they call it finished. So they did... but it's not satisfying. This seems to happen even with bigger-name episodic games, like Life is Strange. It is simply hard to maintain quality and cohesion this way.

Steam tags call this an "RPG," but ACE isn't and by trying to be (with a kind-of "story arc" and characters "classes"), it dilutes itself. In actuality it is "slice of life" and should have embraced that. Drop the abortive mystery and rivalry and just be about a schoolboy and his friends. As written, this practically begs for a continuation or sequel that seems unlikely. That's too bad, because the bones of a really compelling VN are here. I would love to learn more about GEARs and how they define people's lives. I would love to keep following these characters and their relationships beyond the beginning stage (but that's a general gripe for too many VNs).

But still, I do recommend ACE Academy, maybe with the caveat of waiting for a sale. If you like VNs (and if you're reading this, you very likely do), I believe this game will be enjoyable, but not mind-blowing, for you. It was good enough on its own merits, and has me interested in PixelFade's further work. Apparently in their next game, Crystalline, there is only one love interest for the main character that will be relatively complicated and fleshed-out. That's a very promising direction in today's mile-wide, inch-deep world of dating sims.

33760011.review:
Disclaimer: I've only played through one route at the time of writing this review. I will update it if my opinion were to change after I play through the others.

I found out about this game through their initial Kickstarter, back when its name was something completey different and so was the setting. Little to say, I was really excited when they were finally releasing the final product but man... was I just so disappointed with how rushed and incomplete the game feels.

Let's begin with the battle system. I understand it wasn't their focus at all, but that's no excuse to how lazily done it is. The player really doesn't have to even think at all, especially when you add options that are literally "Get hit". I think adding some depth to it would've been great, because the way it is right now it's so easy to beat that it's not even fun.

The background art is reused over and over and over again. The Pilot's Lounge and the Schoolgrounds were used for about 4 or 5 different locations EACH, with other beings used multiples times as well, though in less amounts. It just feels lazy, and ruins the atmosphere of the scenes when everything looks like it's happening in the same places.

The story.... oh god. Easily the biggest issue with ACE Academy. Honestly, the things I mentioned above could've been overlooked if the game's story didn't feel SOOOOO rushed. I won't go into specifics to avoid spoilers, but don't expect anything serious about this game. Any build-up it'd done gets killed completely, the problems are gone as quick as they appear. It honestly feels more like a joke and makes me feel dumb for even expecting something more of this.

And that's just what I feel like going in-depth about. There's a bunch of other issues with this game too. Like how they introduce new characters but never bother to do anything meaningful with them; somewhat important side-characters just using the default black sillhouette as oppose to getting their unique art; humour being done through references and punsh like "Ceonardo DiLaprio" A LOT (it's funny at first, but it doesn't take long until it feels overused and boring); as well as voice lines not matching the dialogue.

On the positive side... the main characters were fine, I guess. The game never does anything mind-blowing with them, they're pretty generic overall but I enjoyed experiencing their backstories a bit. The soundtrack and CGI aren't anything outstanding either, but they're definitely not bad.

I don't think the game is unplayable, I somewhat enjoyed and I do plan on playing through every route in hope that there's just something I missed that makes it good. But objectively, the pros don't outweight the cons, and it's definitely not something I'd recommend on my own accord. 

If you're interested and don't mind paying its price, go ahead and test if it's your thing. But I'd honestly suggest spending the money on anything else if you aren't really that interesed.

I bought this without much expectations i guess, yet just the beginning was very nice with its calm atmosphere, and really nice Characters... totally dragged me in.

Now after completing the whole thing, gotta say I absolutely loved every minute of it. Unique and overall lovable Characters, pretty humorous conversations and actions which made me laugh more than just a few times an hour, a nice backstory of the Main Character, whom i really liked as well, no matter how you play him, he's amazing, and well the Romance (Personally i chose Kaori) totally hit the spot for me. If she was real, she'd be 100% my type... which I thought was kind of impossible for a game to achieve, since games often like to objectify their characters a bit too much, also keeping them a little raw and one-sided. I'd probably feel bad about myself replaying with another option now though :/ 
It was touching and really cute and I could absolutely relate to her, maybe due to experiences i've made IRL, which is always the best right? Certain nice things to relate to, stuff you know from your own life, knowing others and yourself well n stuff...

In any case there were a few downsides, particularly the backstory which sadly leaves lotsa questions, even though i did like it a lot, the overall satisfying, still slightly too quick ending, the lack of background art, which was often reused for different sites, and also the lack of artwork for different scenes. The artwork was beautiful tho, which is kinda why i would've loved to see more, especially romance ones. Heh >_< 

Those may be a few points but each of them is trivial to me, why i think the pro strongly overpowers the contra. Also let's be fair, there'd have to be a picture for each romance option everytime, which would've escalated quickly, and the game is pumped as it is, far longer than expected, must've been quite a piece of work. On my opinion this is a must have for anyone who prefers quality story and characters over tasteless jokes and fanservice. Absolutely amazing. Loved it! Seriously you guys at PixelFade, thanks ALOT!

33283697.review:
I never really got into visual novels.  I expect them to be the modern equivalent of the choose your own adventures of my youth.  I like branching story paths.  How many hours did I play the origin stories in Dragon Age just to see if the scenes change based on different options?  At least 20.

Most visual novels I tried are translated Japanese games.  Not localised, just translated.  That's never really worked for me.

Ace Academy does work.  Names are easy to remember and identify.  Game is loaded with choices.  About half of them matter for the ongoing story, but all change at least three "paragraphs" of the scene it is in. 

This game doesn't force you to "choose a path" and lock out others like some do.  You have multiple chances at seeing the same scenes with characters.  As an example, you are given three options for who to hang out with.   Next day, you are presented with the other two, or maybe a another third choice.  Sometimes the plot in those other scenes make it pass by you.   It's not like you choose "Shou" and you're locked on the "Shou Path" for the rest of the game.  Even the breakpoint "date" scenes are based on the people you spent time with, so you can have several options.  

The characters in this game have their own plots going on.  And they will go on without your intervention if you don't interact with them.  It's pretty nice that your character isn't the prime motivator of all the plot.

The voice acting is decent.  The best thing is that it is in English, and the voices are not outright annoying to listen to. (an issue I have with most JP visual novels)  The actors are not superstar talents, and it shows.  Some pronunciations are suspect, and actors change how they pronounce another character's names partway through.  It's not recorded in a high end studio an A game would have.  I suspect that the developers did the voices themselves.  That said, the directing and recording quality is perfectly acceptable given the game.  I have heard far, far worse voice acting with bad direction and terrible studio recording.  Ace Academy's voice acting just seems "off" but you easily get used to it.

Gags are, for the most part, decent.  Plenty of room for improvement, but I like the humor style overall.  There is really only one part I dislike, and that is a fourth wall breaking anime convention where the devs tell you how the to make the game.  It's a little too far.

SSparks is absolutely correct in that the plot ball is dropped often.  Narratively speaking, the main plotline is slowly built up during the game.  It is finally revealed, and the game ends ten minutes later with an unsatisfying climax.  The Secret Ending of the game even lets you, the player, demand to see the real ending.  The game explains they ran out of money, and gives a link to Patreon.  Seriously, that's how the game ends.  So much potential.  If you don't have the money to fit your narrative, make your narrative fit your budget.  

The mech combat isn't really used.  They could have removed it completely, and not much would change.  All it is is a timed menu choice.  

Artwork is good, perfectly acceptable.  The only issue is that the "Strange outdated American junker Mech" looks pretty much the same as the "Sleek Modern Japanese Mechs".  In essence, the Japanese mechs should be sport bikes to the protagonist's beat up power cruiser.  

Overall, while I am disappointed with the ending, I found the game to be strong and a sign that visual novels can work for me.  I want to see more western designed VNs like this, or at least fully localized Japanese ones.  I want this game to be a success so others will improve upon it.

This little indie dev has actually managed to capture something in each character that just sparkles when you're interacting with them. 32797951.review:
WARNING: PROBABLY CONTAINS SPOILERS

----

I had been interested in this VN since I saw it on early alpha. The art looked good, and the premise interesting. The final product had both of these, but it lacked a conclusion. I was pretty excited when I saved enough money to buy it, and for the first few hours it was great. Sadly, in the end I was left with what looked like a rushed product. There's so much worldbuilding, plot development, and even some drama, but it's all superficial. Mystery surrounding protagonist's parents? Solved in a few minutes. Mystery around the rival (who isn't even a true rival, he's just there undefeated and being cool) and the company that sponsors him? Solved in a few minutes too. Sister regretting past choices? SOLVED IN A FEW MINUTES! Some minor characters, like the rival sponsor CEO, got a sprite and only appeared for a few seconds. Meanwhile, others like Mitsuki in the Mayu scenes didn't. And if there's one thing that I take seriously, it's girls named Mitsuki.

The soundtrack was so forgettable I can't recall a single track. The humor was pretty much 95% references, including Ceonardo DiLaprio never winning a Moscar and the siblings watching series like Game of GEARs (or was it GEAR of Thrones) and Top GEAR. 4% was meta jokes ("this isn't an anime") and the remaining 1% was weebspeak. The artstyle is good, except for the faces. Those just feel samey. Speaking of faces, they blink. Not sure why this was added, it just made stuff more complicated. The sprites themselves didn't move, they could only blink for eternity. Not even mouth movement synced with the voices. Oh yeah, it was voiced in English. At first I liked it, but after a while they started coming off a bit unnatural, especially Shou and his Broseph, which is the way he called the protagonist to avoid having to say his name in a voiced line. Since, y'know, this is a self insert VN and you get to name him however you want. There's also a choice screen right in the beginning that lets you choose the protag's personality. From what I've seen, that only changes what kinds of choices are highlighted (basically an easy mode). The fight choices are pretty straightforward (even the timed ones, if you miss the timer just scroll one line up and redo it), and the same goes for the relationship ones.

As for technical issues, this is a huge memory hog. It hit 1.2 GB of RAM at some point, and I'm pretty sure it happened because there were six blinking sprites on screen at once. Not only that, but it also lacks a backlog. Now, both of these issues can probably be attributed to the engine used, Ren'Py, which is good for it's price (like really, it's free), so I'll just leave that aside.

It's still an enjoyable VN, but from what I saw, it's not worth more than a 6/10.

32776982.review:
Possibly one of the best western visual novels I’ve played so far, even tho I didn’t liked the ending too much. I’m going to be honest, at first I thought it was going to be an okay title with pretty art, but ACE Academy is actually really good. And one of the keys of success is the MC: he’s funny, kind of a jerk sometimes, can be a sweetheart… I loved him! 

It’s a slice of life with mecha action. I was interested more because of the giant robots at first, but the comedy and character interaction were surprisingly good. There’s a lot of mentions of other famous games (such as Persona 4), the amount of choices and the way that they change the story is awesome, and the voice acting is [b]great[/b]! All VAs did an excellent job on this game, seriously. 

About the routes, I enjoyed Kaori’s a lot. I’m not so fond of the “tsundere” type and yet I liked that character a lot. Her voice fitted her so well that I think that’s one of the reasons why I liked Kaori: the girl is stubborn as hell, but you can feel that deep down she does have a good heart, and she’s not simply grumpy for no reason. Also, I liked Mayu. [spoiler](Yes, the madwoman. Yandere is my guilty pleasure, I’m sorry. lol[/spoiler]

9/10. If you want a good and light comedy to read, you’ll enjoy this VN. But if you don’t like games with “no closure” or with cliffhangers, you might get annoyed. But honestly, the character interaction and the scenarios are so good and enjoyable that I feel like “forgiving” the ending. I really hope that there will be a sequel someday!

32748888.review: Awesome game hope theres a second one :)

32738203.review:
AAAAAAAAAAAAAGHHH I THOUGHT YOU HAD MY BACK BROSEPH! GIVE ME MORE CONTENT! 

I just finished my first full playthrough of the game, And I am filled with a wave of sadness that I feel after finishing any DAMNN GOOD visual novel.
I call it 'Visual Novel Depression'. And my emotions right now are sky high....

I am struggling to put how good ACE Academy Is into words...
It can be funny at times, it can be absolutely hilarious at times, it can be serious at times, it can be saddening at times, it can be corny at times, and it can be downright heartbreaking at times.
So many emotions filled me when I played this game.

ACE Academy is set in the year 2049 and is the story of a young man (Name chosen by the player) who is an American transfer student in Japan and is sent into the country's most prestigious mecha pilot program at ACE Academy. The mecha in this game are named GEAR.
I won't give away any more of the story, but there are a number of girls that you can romance, all followed up by a compelling story worth investing your time into.

This Visual Novel has a number of quirks that kept me entertained, and the thrill of jumping into the cockpit of a mecha is unmatched and it left me feeling anxious before every battle. 
ALL the main characters have distinct personalities and for the most part are very likeable people (Yes, even Kaori), I wanted to spend as much time as I could with everyone. I will definitely go back and play the other routes.

The art quality in this Visual Novel varies. You can definitely tell it was crowdfunded. Some artwork can be absolutely outstanding, yet others lack appeal or variety. I guess it was smart use of the artist(s)' time but I would have liked to of seen more scenes and environments, and some characters are lacking models, being replaced with just generic silhouettes.
The music, while repetitive at times, generally fits the scene really well and can really drive home the emotion that the game is trying to project on the player at any given time.

Still though, the game is fully voiced in English with exception to the main character. Which is rare to see in a Visual Novel.
I thoroughly enjoyed the voice acting! It's great for the most part. Some unimportant characters lack enthusiasm at times, but I was generally impressed.
Some of the voice actors definitely have a big future in the industry If they so choose to pursue it.

This has been one of the best visual novels I have ever played, to date, And the limited budget that this game was made on makes the achievement that PixelFade has accomplished even sweeter.
Their team has managed to create a memory I will never forget. A true experience.

The witty and creative writing pulled many genuine laughs from me, with many jokes and references from the real world included in the game's world.

While a lot of the game's outcome is static, there are still a lot of great dialogue options, with some leading to absolutely GENUINELY FUNNY responses! I had to go back and select a few different options most times, as I wanted to hear what the characters had to say. 
Fortunately the game's autosave feature makes this very easy to do, as the game will have multiple savepoints during choices requiring the player's input.

The Visual Novel is also not shy to make fun of itself as well, even breaking the fourth wall. All in good taste.

This VN sets the benchmark for the rest of the genre and is definitely worth the price. (If you catch it on sale then please support the devs on Patreon or something! They really deserve it)
I didn't know this was an indie game until I realized it at the game's ending credits. I would have been led to believe otherwise if it wasn't mentioned.

I can't believe I didn't pick this up sooner.

Wonderful!

TL;DR:

+ Story execution was totally nailed.
+ Great humor, I laughed more times than I laugh at any 'comedy' movie, and the story still managed to be emotionally investing. 
+ Characters have genuine, likeable personalities.
+ Fully voiced in English
+ It's genuinely fun. I don't usually binge play or binge watch things. It usually takes me days to finish a full length movie. I couldn't stop playing this however!
+ Quirky and very intelligent script writing.
+++ You get to pilot a freaking mecha! Who doesn't love that?

~ Artwork quality varies, Some characters are just silhouettes
~ Music mostly repetitive, however appropriate for the situation

- Full story only took about 9.5 hours to complete. (One romance route). Harsh giving this a negative considering the game's limited budget and resources.
- There's so much more that could have been explored with the main story. A few things left unexplained.

PLEASE OH PLEASE GIVE ME A SEQUEL ONE DAY. (Maybe I will have to wait until 2049....)

DAMN YOU PIXELFADE, I WANT MORE!

Also, possibly due to an error in my part I ended up trying to court a taken woman for about 9 hours before realizing my mistake, so it certainly qualifies as a simulator in my books... Funny...

32646631.review:
Originally I played the demo of Pixelfade's upcoming game 'Crystalline' and was suprised by the quality of their work, since I am someone who usually plays japanese visual novels and prefers to stay cleer from english ones. I immediately decided to back their project and check out their other works. Which is the reason I bought their previous VN Ace Academy.

Despite the fact that I haven't completed all routes yet, I really enjoyed the ones I have played so far (Yuuna's and Kaori's). The two main factors being the top notch voice acting (I enjoyed Nikí's VA the most) and the humorous script, which the writers really excell at: the comedy isn't over the top and as a result the serious moments appear realistic (and are able to convey an emotional meaning).

However, there are some let downs: Because I was impressed by the rest of the vn I was disappointed by the ending that was sort of anti-climatic: I would have liked to see an ending that would would stay true to the rest to the quality of the VN. Also, the different routes still overlap at many points, which is a let down to someone (like me) who wants to do all routes and has to read the same lines over again.

But don't let that stop you from buying this VN: after I encountered this VN I have tried several other english visual novels, but almost none of them reach the quality of this developer. I am sure Pixelfade will set the standard for many english visual novels to come. I would also recommend anyone who reads this review to play their next (fantasy) visual novel 'Crystalline', when it releases and to support the developer via their Patreon.

32555489.review:
I'm wasn't expecting to enjoy this is much as I did. You are a mech pilot coming over to Japan from the US after an accident kills your parents. At which point it's as straightforward as you expect. You meet a variety young ladies, a best friend and deal with your younger sister and go about choosing which one you like best and hanging out with them. 

Despite it's formulaic plot it is very well written both interjects humor both in it's situations and more importantly from the writing itself. While each girl in and of herself comes of as the tropes you'd see in an anime (The innocent nice girl, the kinda slut, the shy nerd, and the aggressive jock) all of them are infused with enough personality that I found myself overlooking the fact that they were all tropes. It also does a nice job giving them realistic backstories that don't come off as either "really that bothers you," or "why are all of your lives terrible." I found myself laughing out loud on a number of occasions in particular when dealing with the younger sister character who as an older brother myself understood perfectly where the main character was coming from so kudo's to the writers for doing a nice job with that dynamic. I also appreciated that the game would thrown in timers to force you to make quick decisions keeping the reader engaged and giving it a more game like feel than other visual novels.

The only drawback and criticism I have of this is the voice acting. While the characters Valarie, Nikki, and Shou are pretty good the rest aren't great. I'm glad the game decided to go forward with voice acting but takes a little bit of getting used to as it isn't great. 

So if you're looking to get into visual novels a few things to remember. These kinds of games are meant for be replayed as a standard play through is between 3-4 hours. Which at $20 may be a bit high if you only want to play it once. However there are so many likable characters that I can see many playing this more than once. 

Final Grade A-

32419044.review:
Jeg formoder at dette vil være den første anmeldelse af Ace Acedemy skrevet på dansk. Det kunne sagtens være blevet en omgang engelsk, men jeg følte for at gå lidt imod strømmen.

OBS: Det er reelt set en håndfuld måneder siden at jeg faktisk spillede AA, samt jeg gennemfik kun 2 af de 5 "routes", som spillet indeholder. For de uindviede er en "route" eller rute, hvad der svarer til et sammenhængende handlingsspor, der for langt de fleste populære "visuelle noveller/romaner", er defineret ud fra hvem ens romantiske interesse er.

Intro til AA: Ace acedemy er en vestligt(Can/USA/EU) udviklet visuel roman, der i modsætning til de fleste andre af disse lader til at have haft et mere solidt økonomisk grundlag. Næsten alle større og mere populære VN's er japanske. Derfor syntes jeg selv at AA er et frisk pust i en genre der kan syntes at være lidt for domineret af de samme clicheer og forudsigelige persontyper man finder i de fleste østlige(japanske) VN. Ace Acedemy tager i stedet disse clicheer og gør på egen måde grin med de mange stereotyper og er i det hele taget fyldt med en masse popkulturelle referencer, memes og trolling af mange typer.

Rammerne: Ace Acedemy foregår engang om nogle årtier i 40'erne eller 50'erne og der er en række småfuturistiske elementer, hvoraf det væsentligste er eksistensen af mechs, dvs. menneskestyrede kampplatforme med 2 arme og ben. I AA er det dog kun i trænings og konkurenceregi at disse maskiner ses, da vores hovedperson er studerende og mech pilot på Ace Acedemy, som vistnok har et lidt mere fancy japansk navn.
Ja, spillet foregår på en japansk high school og hvis man i det hele taget er ret skeptisk hvad anime og dennes subkultur angår, så kan det godt være at man bare skal lede efter spil andre steder.

Historie/handling: Dette nok ikke Ace Acedemy's stærkeste side, da det primære handlingsforløb ikke rigtigt føles tilendegjort, når man sider og bladrer gennem rulleteksterne. Man når simpelthen ikke at se konsekvenserne af de mange valg man træffer i løbet af historien. Handlingen er overvejende let og komisk i tonen, men formår stadig at være rimelig seriøs på de rigtige tidspunkter. 

Gameplay: Der er egentlig ikke så meget af komme efter, da det netop er en visuel roman vi har med at gøre. Man klikker sig gennem handlingen på samme måde som man læser linjer i en bog, blot med computer grafik og musik til at forbedre oplevelsen undervejs. Sammenlignet med andre visuelle noveller foretager man i AA langt flere personlige valg. De fleste af disse valg gør dog kun en forskel i dialogen og den læste tekst, men både ved de store og små valg, føles det som om at der fakisk er konsekvenser. Man har i det hele taget gode muligheder for at spille en "role play" som en bestemt slags person og få noget ud af det. 
I kraft af ens valg er det også at man kan tilbringe mere eller mindre tid med de 4 "heroines/heltinder" eller ens bedste ven der i udpræget grad fungerer som comic relief. Alt efter ens preferæncer vil man låse sig fast på et underliggende romatisk handlingsspor med en af heltinderne eller ingen af dem.

Personer: Personerne og udviklingen af deres indbyrdes forhold, er i kraft en det mangelfulde handlingsforløb, nok Ace Academys største trækplaster. Derfor en kort beskrivelse af de vigtigste personer:
MC(main character): 21 år, Amerikaner på xx år, blond, atlestisk/intuitiv/klog(eget valg)
Nikki: 17 år, Lillesøster, sød, manipulerende, blond, 
Kaori: Rødt hår, tsundere(arrigog vred det meste af tiden), arbejdsom,
Yuuna: 21 år, Lilla/lyserødt hår, hjælpsom, team maneger(eller noget lignende),
Valerie: 20 år, Fransk, mech mekaniker/ingeniør, klogere end man får indtryk af, flirtende, blond
Mayu: 20 år, Blåsort hår, genert, venlig, ifølge spiludviklerens forum, den værste af heltinderne.
Shou: 21 år, Mørkblond hår, mech pilot, comic relief, baseret på Yusuke fra Persona 4, (over)entusiatisk, lidt pervers, etc.
Kaito: Yngre 30'ere, mørkt hår, onkel via MC og Nikki's mor, lidt en ungkarl.


Andet godt: Mere eller mindre al dialog med undtagelse af jeg-personen selv, har engelske stemmer. I AA gør stemmeskuespillerne et så godt stykke arbejde, at jeg vil vove at påstå at der ikke findes bedre indenfor visuelle romaner på engelsk.
De visuelle elementer er i det hele taget godt udført, både sprites(2D tegninger af personerne), baggrunde og CG's(computergenererede billeder) er flotte. 
Soundtracket passer i øvrigt også godt sammen med rammerne og skaber en tilpas futuristisk, men hverdagsagtig atmosfære.

Resten af det mindre gode: Man kan til tider godt savne at der måske var et lidt større antal baggrunde. Det giver mening at bruge samme baggrund for f. eks hovedpersonens soveværelse, klasseværelse og mech garage, men der er også enkelte gange hvor man bemærker samme baggrund ved eller ret forskellige lokaliteter.
Som tidligere nævnt, skulle spillet have været lidt længere, så man på den måde kunne få sluttet handlingen ordenligt af. Det føles lidt som om at køre rundt på en racerbane og så løbe tør for brændstof en runde eller 3 før mål.

Alt i alt: Jeg vil da gerne anbefale dette spil til dem som godt kan lide en komisk og lethjertet oplevelse, inklusive et måske lidt "fluffy/nuttet" romantisk subplot. Langt de fleste der rent faktisk har en bruger her på steam burde finde især humoren tiltalende.

Lad vær at investere eller vent på et steam sale, hvis en eller flere gælder: 
Du er typen der resolut foretrækker mere seriøse plotlines, 
ikke kan fordrage MOE(japansk begreb, google det), 
er en weeb hater, 
svært foretrækker 3D gameplay, 
har begrænset tid at bruge på spil, visuelle noveller kræver relativt meget tid og er ikke egnet til en hurtig session på en halv times spil eller mindre.
